ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RESETTLEMENT OF SHOPKEEPERS IN SEMBAWANG
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for National Development and

Column: 1428

Communications (a) how many units of shophouses in Sembawang are affected by road-widening; (b) whether the shop owners who are affected will be given alternative shop premises; and (c) in order to assist the affected shop owners to overcome their resettlement problems, if they will be granted concessionary rates of rentals for their new premises.

Column: 1429



     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 105 shop cases in 91 units of shophouses affected by the proposed widening of Sembawang Road - Stage III from Jalan Sembawang Kechil to Admiralty Road).

    Shopkeepers affected by the clearance will be offered alternative premises in accordance with the present resettlement policy.

    Resettled shopkeepers who are Singapore citizens and not sharing premises are entitled to rental concession spread over a period of five years. They pay 50% of the rental in the first year. This is increased by 10% each year and it is only in the sixth year that they will pay the full rent.

Column: 1429

PEDESTRIAN CROSSING AT MARSILING LANE


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether consideration would be given to provide a zebra crossing at Blocks 17 and 18, Marsiling.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, recent pedestrian traffic counts showed that there is no justification for providing a pedestrian crossing across Marsiling Lane at Apartment Blocks 17 and 18. Pedestrians will have little difficulty in crossing the road as there are sufficient gaps in the traffic flow to allow for it. However, it was found that a pedestrian crossing is required across Marsiling Road near its junction with Marsiling Lane. A suitable crossing, either zebra or push button crossing, would be provided at this location.

Column: 1429

PERMANENT RESIDENCE FOR SPECIAL PASS HOLDERS
(Request for)


    3. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education whether he will consider granting permanent

Column: 1430

residence to a Special Pass holder whose family includes permanent residents or Singapore citizens.

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, Special Pass holders are normally persons who are unable to prove their lawful presence in Singapore but are allowed to remain here on purely compassionate grounds. Where the grant of permanent residence is concerned, they are treated on the same basis as others who are staying here lawfully on other types of immigration passes. Special Pass holders cannot claim special privilege over these other people who may also have family ties in Singapore.

    The grant of permanent residence is governed by the provisions of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1973. Family roots is only one factor when considering applications for permanent residence. Much will depend on whether the applicant has special skill and can contribute or have contributed to the well-being of the country. Generally, a Special Pass holder who is a professional or skilled person, the wife of a Singapore citizen, or a child under the age of six of a Singapore citizen, is eligible for the grant of permanent resident status. Alternatively, if he is a male of national service age, he can also be considered for permanent residence provided he signs up for regular service in the SAF.

    During the last five years, 400 persons who were previously on Special Passes were granted permanent residence. They included those whose families are made up of Singapore citizens or permanent residents.

     Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in his reply the Minister says that those with special skills or technical skills or those who sign up for national service will be given consideration for permanent residence. I would like to ask the Minister whether those who are, say, above 30 years want to join national service or any uniformed organisation, will be considered for permanent residence.

Column: 1431



     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Sembawang had listened to the answer carefully, he would have noticed that what I said was that consideration would be given on joining the SAF regular service, and not doing national service. If a male person is over 30 years old and if he is accepted as a regular of the SAF, then of course, he will be considered for the grant of permanent residence. But there is a difference between doing national service and being in the service of the SAF. I hope this clarifies the mind of the Member for Sembawang.

Column: 1431

REVISION OF ATTENDANCE FEES
AND DENTAL SERVICE CHARGES
(Statement by the Minister for Health)

2.37 p.m.

Accident & Emergency Fees

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the debate on the budget of the Ministry of Health the Member for Anson mentioned of rumours on my Ministry's intention to increase the attendance fee at Accident & Emergency (A&E) departments in the hospitals. I am using this opportunity to inform the House that the Member for Anson is a good fortune teller and he has made the rumours come true.

    During a press conference last year I mentioned misutilisation of A&E departments. Of the attendances at A&E departments in a 4-month period, 72.8% were self-referrals, 9.4% by general practitioners, 5.1% by the Ministry's Outpatient Dispensaries (OPD's), 3.8% by the Police and 8.9% by others. Only 17.8% of patients were considered serious for admission into hospital and 16.7% were referred to specialist clinics. On the other hand, as high as 61.9% of patients were discharged after examination and the remaining 3.5% were asked to go back to their OPD's.

Column: 1432



    The Member for Kim Seng told the House last week of his own personal experiences with National Service patients referred to the Singapore General Hospital. Most of the referrals according to him had minor ailments which could and should be treated by Army doctors in their camps but are not. This is confirmatory evidence that the hospitals are being misused.

    In A&E departments doctors assume that the patients who turn up are serious or emergency cases. To be fair to such genuine patients, doctors require a longer time to examine them. It is important that doctors in A&E departments should know when a stomach ache is due to acute appendicitis which requires surgery and do not dismiss it as gastritis or a stomach upset from eating contaminated food. But if doctors in A&E departments are faced with large numbers of patients with minor ailments, their mental alertness becomes dulled and mistakes can be made. Patients, who go to A&E departments or visit specialist clinics should now understand why they have long waiting times before being examined or admitted into a ward.

    I have circulated to Members figures (Cols. 1471 - 1472) showing an increasing trend in A&E attendances for the last four years. Something must be done now if the services at A&E departments are not to break down. Having discussed this problem with Medical Superintendents of hospitals and Heads of A&E departments, we have come to the conclusion that because the existing attendance fee of $4 is too low patients with minor complaints or who have a cough and running nose are crowding into A&E departments. In order to protect the efficiency of A&E departments, the Ministry has therefore decided to raise the A&E attendance fee to $10. If patients deserve admission into hospital for treatment, the $10 will be credited to the minimum deposit of $20 which Class C patients have to pay on admission.
figures - ATTENDANCES AT A & E DEPARTMENTS FOR PERIOD 1974 - 1977, COMPARISON OF A & E ATTENDANCES FOR OCTOBER-DECEMBER 1976 and 1977 (Cols. 1471 - 1472)


    Victims in public disasters such as those who were caught in the stampede at the

Column: 1433

National Stadium last year will be treated free.

    Currently, blood donors do not pay fees at OPD's. But I am prepared to extend this concession at A&E departments to regular blood donors, i.e. those who have in the year made two donations.

    Discretion already exists in A&E departments to waive charges in the case of destitute patients. That discretion remains and patients who are really poor will continue to be treated without payment.

Outpatient Dispensary Fees

    Now let me come to the Outpatient Dispensaries. Patient attendances have increased by 13% from 2.45 million in 1975 to 2.77 million in 1977. At the same time, a 3-day supply of medicine is given to OPD patients. Some industries may have collapsed during the current recession and inflation but the pharmaceutical industry continues to flourish because of continuing demand for medicinal products. What it means is that expenditure on drugs will always be upwards. The Ministry has therefore decided to increase the attendance fee at OPD's by 50 cents during weekdays which is less than the price of two cups of coffee. The increase will be $1 during Sundays and public holidays. The existing attendance fee of 50 cents for children and students on weekdays and $1 for Psychiatric Outpatient Clinics remain unchanged. In spite of this revision the Government will continue to subsidise 60% of the cost per patient attendance.

Dental Service Charges

    Now, let me come to the revision of dental service charges. At the opening of the Institute of Dental Health in September last year, I warned that there should be a review of the present system of dental service charges. The cost per patient attendance was $8.60 while the amount recovered was only 90 cents.

Column: 1434



    The review has been completed and Members have been given a comparative table (Cols. 1473 - 1478) showing the present system and the proposed revised charges.
table - PRESENT AND PROPOSED NEW SCHEME OF DENTAL TREATMENT CHARGES, LIST OF ORAL SURGICAL OPERATIONS (Cols. 1473 - 1478)


    The means test based on monthly family income to distinguish between full-paying and part-paying patients cannot be effectively enforced. Family incomes are invariably understated to avoid paying higher dental charges. Patients obviously do not believe that honesty is the best policy. By the time the Minister for Finance admitted at this Sitting that there are at least 150,000 persons who are earning incomes that are chargeable for income tax but he has found no way to make them pay, it is naive to expect the Ministry of Health to operate a system of full-paying patients and part-paying patients based on a means test. In truth less than 1% of patients seeking dental treatment have been full-paying patients.

    A general medical practitioner takes on the average 2-4 minutes to examine a patient but a dentist takes much more time to treat a patient. In some cases more than one visit is necessary. However, the present dental fees are not related to time and labour and are low compared to the costs of medical outpatient treatment.

    The revised scheme of dental treatment charges replaces the present system of an attendance fee plus additional treatment charges by a single fee related to the treatment required. This reflects no more than what is being practised by dentists in the private sector. However, there will be two scales of charges. Singapore residents, including those who hold work permits or employment passes, will pay lower Scale B fees while non-residents and consultation cases will pay Scale A rates. Under the present system children who go to hospital or an outpatient dental clinic have to pay fees while those who have been given comprehensive dental care at the school dental clinics are not charged. Under the revised scheme, children and students will pay 20% of Scale B rates in order to remove the anomaly.

Column: 1435



    This means that students and children who pay an average fee of 50 cents per attendance will now pay an average fee of 88 cents.

    For adults where the average attendance fee is $3.51 it will now be $4.50.

    In spite of the revision, Government subsidy on dental services will be 80% of annual recurrent costs excluding capital expenditure. This heavy subsidy is due to the fact that the majority of those receiving treatment are children and students.

Column: 1435

SUPPLY BILL


    Order for Second and Third Readings read.
2.46 p.m.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    In accordance with Article 85 of the Constitution of Singapore, heads of expenditure to be met from the Consolidated Fund other than statutory expenditure have to be included in a Bill to be known as the Supply Bill. The purpose of the Supply Bill before Members is therefore to give legislative approval for the appropriations from the Consolidated Fund to meet expenditure in the financial year 1st April, 1978 to 31st March, 1979.

    The heads of expenditure and the sums that may be incurred in respect of each head are shown in the Schedule to the Bill. These have been approved by the House in the Main Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st April, 1978 to 31st March, 1979, and appear on page 25 of Command Paper No. 2 of 1978.

    The Supply Bill, when approved, will empower me to issue warrants authorising expenditure up to the amount for each head as shown in the Bill to be paid out from the Consolidated Fund.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.

ENLISTMENT (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
2.50 p.m.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    At present, people who are enlisted for national service are liable to render full-time service in the Singapore Armed Forces for two years. However, those who are selected for officer training or who have been promoted above the rank of Lance Corporal

Column: 1437

are liable to serve 2 1/2 years. For equity purposes, it is necessary to extend the same liability of 2 1/2 years to those full-time national servicemen in the Police Force, the Vigilante Corps, the Singapore Fire Brigade and the Aerodrome Fire Service who are trained to hold a rank equivalent to that of an officer in the Singapore Armed Forces or who are promoted to a rank equal to that of Corporal and above in the SAF.

    We have noted that employers in the past were generally reluctant to give temporary employment to persons who are liable for national service call-up because, under the law now in force, these employers are obliged to reinstate the servicemen after they have completed their national service. So legislation which is intended to assist young men has in practice worked out to their detriment and this is a clear case of counter-productive legislation. To rectify this situation and to encourage employers to give temporary employment to young persons, awaiting national service call-up, the obligation of reinstatement is now removed. Employers are no longer prohibited from terminating the service of temporary employees in their employment by reason of their liability to be called up to perform national service. This will make it easier for school leavers to get paid employment while waiting for their NSF call-up.

    Under the present law, employers are required to pay their employees who are performing reserve, voluntary or mobilised service the difference between the employees' civilian pay and service pay. Employers are then allowed to obtain reimbursement of this amount by deducting from their payroll tax or by claiming reimbursement from the designated authority. This cumbersome procedure is to be replaced by a simple one whereby the Ministry of Defence pays directly to the employees doing reservist or other forms of training the difference between their civilian pay and service pay. This new procedure will also apply to the Ministry of Home Affairs which looks after the Special Constabulary, Vigilante Corps, Singapore Fire Brigade and the Singapore Aerodrome Fire Service.

Column: 1438

Under the new procedure when the employees are called up for service or training, their employers will have to submit to the relevant units details in prescribed forms of the employees' civilian pay. The make-up pay will then be computed by the paymasters of units and be added to their service pay where civilian pay exceeds service pay.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill - [Dr Goh Keng Swee]

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 1438

SINGAPORE ARMED FORCES
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
2.56 p.m.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    There is always the possibility that ex-servicemen, whether regular or national service, may divulge protected defence information. As such persons have ceased to be subject to military law except during the time they are actually performing reservist training and they cannot be tried by a military court for such offences. It is now intended that a subordinate military court will have jurisdiction to try such persons for the offence of divulging protected information. For this purpose, such persons are to be regarded as continuing to be subject to military law in respect of unauthorised disclosure of protected defence information. The provisions of the Act relating to the arrest, detention in custody, investigation of offences, trial and punishment by the subordinate military court in connection with such offences and execution of any sentence passed shall apply to them.

Column: 1439



    Presently, persons subject to military law who are accused of murder or culpable homicide not amounting to murder or with an offence under section 121 and 121A of the Penal Code may be tried by a subordinate military court, the President of which must be a Judge of the Supreme Court appointed by the Chief Justice. Where an accused is to be found guilty of a charge for which the punishment is death, the decision of the subordinate military court must be unanimous. Other than those presently listed in the Act, there are offences carrying the death penalty; for example, certain offences under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1973, which may be committed by persons subject to military law and be tried by the subordinate military court. It is necessary that the Act be amended to provide for the President of the court martial trying such other offences carrying the death penalty to be a Supreme Court Judge appointed by the Chief Justice and for a decision of such a court martial to be unanimous.

    Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1973, a certificate relating to a controlled drug signed by a Government Chemist is admissible as evidence in proceedings. He need not appear in court to testify to his signature. It will be considered as prima facie evidence of all matters contained in it. A provision is now made to give a Singapore Armed Forces Pharmacist or Chemist the same legal standing. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1973, a person who has been required to provide a specimen of his urine for a urine test has the right to apply for a second test of his urine specimen. This is to ensure that the accused is not convicted due to any error in the handling or analysis of his urine sample. It is intended that the right to apply for a second urine test should also be accorded to SAF personnel and power is given to the Armed Forces Council to set aside the conviction and sentence if, as a result of the second test, it is found that there is no controlled drug in the urine specimen. The power to set aside a conviction and sentence is necessary as drug offences in the SAF are dealt with and concluded very swiftly. This is

Column: 1440

in the interest of soldiers who otherwise would have to remain in detention for weeks or months on end.

    When a person subject to military law is convicted of a non-military offence other than murder, culpable homicide, rape and the Penal Code offence under section 121 (Waging War Against The Government) or section 121A (Offences Against The President's Person), a subordinate military court is given the power to pass the sentence provided for the non-military offence. In addition to or in lieu of such punishment, the court may impose military punishment, for example, discharge with ignominy, reduction in rank or forfeiture of military decoration or military award. Such an additional power of punishment is necessary when dealing with military personnel in the context of the Singapore Armed Forces.

    In the civil court, when a person is officially informed that he may be prosecuted for an offence, he is requested to mention any fact that he intends to rely in his defence so that it may be written down. This procedure is also to be made available to a person subject to military law. The law also provides that adverse inferences may be drawn if he fails to mention any such fact. This is similarly to be incorporated.

    The authority to write-off any public stores and public monies is conferred on the Minister for Finance and accordingly all cases relating to public stores or public monies have to be referred to the Ministry of Finance. In the Singapore Armed Forces, cases of loss, damage or destruction of public property may be dealt with by way of summary trial, court martial or Boards of Inquiry. Under these procedures, the Armed Forces Council may issue an order to recover total or part value of the lost, damaged or destroyed property. When part recovery of the value is made, the unrecovered portion has to be written off and the matter has to be referred to the Ministry of Finance for its authority for the write-off. As the request for the authority to write off is made on the basis of a decision of the Armed Forces Council, the authority is given as a matter of formality. Accordingly for

Column: 1441

administrative expediency and to relieve the Ministry of Finance of the responsibility in authorising write-off in respect of matters on which they have very little say, the power is now to be given to the Armed Forces Council to write off the value of public stores and public monies under the charge of the SAF which are lost, damaged or destroyed.

    Pensions, gratuities or other allowances granted to military personnel are paid out of the Consolidated Fund and, except for the purpose of satisfying a debt due to the Government or a court order for the payment of maintenance of the serviceman's wife or children, they are not assignable or transferable or liable to be attached to satisfy. a debt or claim. The provisions appear in the Singapore Army Pensions Scheme Regulations, 1971 which have since been revoked and replaced by the Singapore Armed Forces Pensions Regulations, 1978. It is more appropriate for these provisions to appear in the Act and therefore a new section has been introduced.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Dr Goh Keng Swee].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 1441

SINGAPORE RED CROSS SOCIETY (INCORPORATION)

(AMENDMENT) BILL

(As reported from Select Committee)


    Order for Third Reading read.
3.06 p.m.

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Third time."

    Members of the House would have read the Official Report of the Select Committee and the reasons for the proposed amendments. The President of the Republic

Column: 1442

of Singapore will now only be the Patron of the Society and the Society will be headed by a Chairman who will be appointed by the President of the Republic of Singapore. However, the Honourary Treasurer will no longer be appointed.

    Members of the Society felt that it was necessary to enlarge the powers of the Council to enable it to recruit and train volunteers, in addition to full-time staff to carry out the functions of the Society. Accordingly the Committee has made an amendment to section 9 of the Act enlarging the powers of the Council. Under section 9 of the principal Act, the President of the Society approves the rules of the Council. With the abolition of the post of the President of the Society, it is necessary to amend section 9 so that the Director of Medical Services will approve the rules of the Council. The Society has no objections to the amendment to section 5(A) of the principal Act on Objects of the Society.

    Mr Speaker, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Third time and passed.

Column: 1442

FACTORIES (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
3.10 p.m.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Hon. Members will recall that the House in February 1973 passed the Bill which was enacted as the Factories Act 1973. Introduced by the Government then as a result of its concern over the trend of the increasing number of industrial accidents, the Act sought to improve safety, health and welfare provisions as well as to ensure a more stringent observance of safety standards.

    Sir, in the five years since the House dealt with the matter, the industrial safety situation has improved. It is gratifying to note that hon.

Column: 1443

Members have also been as vocal as they are concerned with the well-being of our workers as evidenced by the lively discussions in this House in the Budget debates over the years. Some of their pertinent observations and suggestions which the Minister found to be feasible have also been incorporated in this Amendment Bill.

    Based on the criteria used by the American National Standards Institute, the accident frequency and severity rates in 1973 were 6.8 accidents per million man-hours worked and 1,282 man-days lost per million man-hours worked. In 1977, the accident frequency and severity rates recorded a decline to 5.3 and 501 respectively. In absolute numbers, however, there were in 1973, 2,910 industrial accidents involving 73 fatalities as compared to 4,575 accidents with 57 fatalities in 1977.

    Nevertheless, the number of industrial accidents remains high. It is a matter of continuing concern on the part of the Government. The economic cost of these accidents is large. With manpower as our only dependable resource, we cannot afford to see our workers maimed or killed. More importantly, the social cost is high and cannot be measured by plain statistics. There is the pain, misery and anguish of the worker and his family in every accident. We must avoid this human suffering especially as they are caused by accidents which often need not have happened at all.

    The safety and health situation in industrial establishments should be further improved. The administration of the Factories Act since its enactment in 1973 shows that the law needs to be further strengthened to meet with the increasing sophistication in our technological advancement and it is for this purpose that this Amendment Bill is before the House. The proposed Amendments seek to provide for safer working conditions as well as better enforcement of the Factories Act to ensure that its provisions are complied with.

    The proposed amendments to the Factories Act are described in the Explanatory Statement to the Bill. I should like, however, to highlight some of the more salient features.

Accident statistics in the past two years have shown that there were more than 2,000 accidents involving the use of machinery. Analysis made on the causes of these accidents revealed a combination of several factors - lack of awareness on the part of the workers on the danger associated with the machinery they handle, poor maintenance of machinery and the absence of adequate training to provide the operators with a thorough knowledge of the machines' peculiarities or potential hazards.

    To meet with this situation, a number of amendments have been proposed. Clause 7 of the Bill which amends section 24 proVides for the proper maintenance of machinery and plant installed in factories. This new provision will minimise the danger of injury to which the workers are exposed or to more nasty consequences as a result of machinery or plant breaking down.

With the introduction of this new provision, neither the worker, the safety personnel or supervisor, nor the employer can plead ignorance, a common tactic frequently employed when accidents occur. It will facilitate more effective and speedier inspection by the enforcement officers.

    Clause 20 of the Bill seeks to amend section 61 of the principal Act by empowering the Minister to make regulations to prescribe the qualifications and training of persons who are employed at any machine or plant. This is an important provision, particularly for construction worksites where accidents involving mobile cranes, excavators and bulldozers are caused

Column: 1445

mainly by operators who are not sufficiently trained in the handling of such heavy mobile machinery and plant.

    Another area where similar upgrading of safety measures is most expedient is the shipbuilding and repairing industry, where working in confined spaces and in explosive or inflammable environment is common. Hon. Members are well aware that deficiency of oxygen is a hazard ever-present in confined spaces, particularly where a number of workers are deployed in one confined space, and if the oxygen depletion process is quickened it may result in multiple fatalities. While the existing Act requires a responsible person to test and certify that a confined space is safe before allowing workers to work in it, the tester is not required to keep records of such tests. This has resulted in poor documentation of such records which frustrates safety management and impedes enforcement. To rectify this defect, clause 11 is introduced to amend section 34 requiring records of such tests to be kept. Further, clause 12 of the Bill which amends section 35 of the Act introduces a new requirement for plants, tanks or vessels which have previously contained explosives or inflammable substances to be inspected before hot work is allowed to be carried out. Stringent adherence to this procedure by Safety Personnel in the factories will certainly ensure the elimination of the presence of explosive or inflammable substances which can cause fire and explosions.

    The Bill also includes amendments providing for better observance of safety standards. Under the present Act, the maximum penalty for infringements of safety provisions which are likely to cause death or bodily injury to any person and other offences for which no expressed penalty has been provided for is a $2,000 fine or an imprisonment not exceeding three months, or both. The seriousness of infringements of this nature need not be further emphasised. The present penalties are in our view not sufficiently adequate to deter persons from committing such infringements. Clause 26, therefore, seeks to amend section 82 of the

Column: 1446

principal Act by providing for enhanced penalties of a maximum fine of $10,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or both.

They cannot obviously be treated lightly and appropriate action must be taken. However, it is a time-consuming exercise to bring every case before the court. The preparation for legal proceedings has in the past immobilised a good number of my officers who should be on the field undertaking enforcement work.     Under the existing provisions of the Pensions Act, a Government officer who has been allowed to retire before the minimum age of retirement to contest Parliamentary elections will qualify for pension benefits in respect of his past service in the Civil Service only when he attains the minimum age of retirement. His dependants will not be eligible for a gratuity if he dies before reaching the minimum retirement age.

    Therefore, the officer who retires to contest Parliamentary elections is at a disadvantage compared with an officer who is allowed to retire under the special circumstances of section 7(2) (j).

    The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Pensions Act so that in the case of a Government officer who is permitted to retire to contest Parliamentary elections -

    (a) he shall be eligible for pension benefits if he becomes physically or mentally incapacitated; and

ESTATE DUTY (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
4.03 p.m.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    For the domiciled deceased person, estate duty is imposed on his total assets in Singapore as well as on his movable assets elsewhere. In the case of a non-domiciled person, estate duty is levied on his movable and immovable properties situate in Singapore only.

Column: 1462



    The rates of estate duty existing before 1st April 1977 ranged between 5% and 60% for estates exceeding $50,000 in value. Estates below $50,000 in value were exempted from duty. Duty was also remitted at a declining rate of 10% of the duty payable for every $20,000 in excess of $50,000. The remission limit was $23,000.

    In my 1977 annual Budget Statement, I announced that, to encourage home ownership and a more stable society comprising home owners, the rates of estate duty would be revised from 1st April 1977. The exemption limit would be raised from $50,000 to $100,000. The rate of remission would remain the same, i.e. at a declining rate of 10% of the duty payable for every $20,000 in excess of $100,000 in value of the estate. The remission limit would be increased to $280,000.

    The Estate Duty (Amendment) Bill seeks to amend the Estate Duty Act accordingly. Clause 2 of the Amendment Bill levies the new rates of estate duty on the property of any person dying on or after 1st April 1977. Clause 3 sets out the remissions including those provided under the Estate Duty (Remission) Order, 1974. Clause 4 of the Bill exempts bequests to statutory institutions as specified in the Twelfth Schedule to the Act from estate duty.

    In a corresponding Bill, which I am taking through the House today, the Statutes of the Republic of Singapore (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, I shall be seeking to delete the estate duty exemption provisions in the various Statutes. These are now more appropriately incorporated in the amendments made by the Bill to the Estate Duty Act.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, clause 4 of the Bill exempts bequests to certain institutions from estate duty. On referring to the Twelfth Schedule, I see that at present only four institutions are in the privileged position of being able to receive bequests which are not subjected to estate

I would say that these two professions have done much better than any other profession over the last few years. They are in a very good financial position. I do not see why we should give them special treatment as such.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That this Parliament, pursuant to paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section 3 of the Bretton Woods Agreements Act (Chapter 61), resolves that the Minister for Finance be authorised to increase, on behalf of the Government, the total subscription of Singapore in the International Monetary Fund to a sum equivalent to 49 million Special Drawing Rights.

    Sir, the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund has adopted a Resolution on Increases in Quota of Fund members - Sixth General Review, under which there will be an overall increase in the Fund's quotas not exceeding 32.5% of the total quotas as of 19th February 1976.

    Quota reviews are conducted by the International Monetary Fund at intervals of approximately five years so that adjustments can be made in members' quotas to reflect changes in their relative economic strength. An important feature of a member's quota is that it determines the scope of a member's access to the resources of the Fund when in balance of payments difficulties and a member's obligations to lend to the Fund on concessionary terms when its balance of payments position is strong.

    At present Singapore's quota in the International Monetary Fund is 37 million Special Drawing Rights. This is equivalent to US$45.4 million, based on exchange rates at the end of February 1978.

    Parliament is requested to authorise the Government to increase Singapore's quota in the International Monetary Fund by a sum of twelve million Special Drawing Rights, equivalent to US$14.7 million, based on exchange rates at the end of February 1978, to a sum not exceeding forty-nine million Special Drawing Rights (SDR 49 million).

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

I think the visit has been fruitful. I think we have been able to convince the team that we fall below the dividing line between what they consider would be developing countries and developed countries.
